reviewText: I have not seen this collection yet but I thought some clarification could be in order.  This set is an expansion of a previous set released by the same company,Sherlock Holmes Collection, with three additional films included.  You'll get 9 films here as opposed to 6 in the other, for about the same price.No, this is not a complete collection of every Sherlock Holmes film, but it is a nice package of films that have entered into the Public Domain.The films included on this are:With BASIL RATHBONE, who played the role in 14 films for Universal Studios:The Woman in Green (1945)Terror by Night (1946)Dressed to Kill (1946)Sherlock Holmes and the Secret Weapon (1943)With ARTHUR WONTNER, who played the role in 5 films, the second of which is lost:The Triumph of Sherlock Holmes (1935)Murder at the Baskervilles (1937) aka The Silver BlazeThe Sign of Four (1932)With RAYMOND MASSEY, his only appearance as Holmes:The Speckled Band (1931)With REGINALD OWEN, his only appearance as Holmes, but had played Watson in an earlier film:A Study in Scarlet (1933)For the price it's a pretty nifty collection and shows what a variety of different actors have done with the role.

reviewText: A "must" for collectors of Sherlock Holmes films. The discs take the viewer through the years of various film styles, Holmes actors, and staging. I gave it 4 stars for historical value. One sees the development and progress of black and white film, photography and sound. As a deaf person, I still am able to enjoy dipping in and out of these no-subtitles discs since I know the mysteries so well. It is exciting to see Arthur Wontnor (sp), who, in earlier years (1929 - 3?) played Holmes in five  films, and understand why so many customers plead for remastering of his films. One feels that  Basil Rathbone used Wontnor as a role model, adding a dash of arrogance to make the role more his own. I recommend this film for collectors as well as Holmes-watchers.

With Rathbone and Bruce on the case, it's Great Entertainment. the price for the set is also great.

reviewText: Since this collection has performances of several different Sherlock Holmes productions, I'll review each individually.  The different portrayals include Basil Rathbone/Nigel Bruce, Arthur Wontner/Ian Fleming, and Ronald Howard/H. Crawford.  Raymond Massey and Reginald Owen each appear once as well.  Rather than review each film, I like to focus on each Watson/Holmes duo.RATHBONEThe Rathbone films are THE WOMAN IN GREEN, TERROR BY NIGHT, DRESSED TO KILL, & SHERLOCK HOLMES AND THE SECRET WEAPON.Rathbone presents the cold, calculating, thinking machine side of Holmes.  He masters the commanding presence of Holmes, though this is sometimes not so good.  For me, Rathbone missed a very important aspect of Holmes' character- his humorous, practical joking, impish side is not displayed at all, which is sort of disappointing.  It makes his character very one-dimensional.  I would give his rendition 4 out of 5 stars.  Watson, on the other hand, lost the majority of his character's, well, character! Nigel Bruce, though very amusing, was too dumbed down, without showing any of Watson's intelligence.  For entertainment's sake, he merits 4 out of 5 stars, but as Holmes' sidekick, he deserves 2 out of 5.  I honestly don't understand how Holmes could even put up with such a bumbler.WONTNERThe Wontner films are TRIUMPH OF SHERLOCK HOLMES,  MURDER AT THE BASKERVILLES, and THE SIGN OF FOUR.Wontner, to put it gently, is not good as Sherlock Holmes.  The trouble is, he does not present Holmes' intelligence, or his humor, or his eccentricity.  He doesn't even look the part, except for his nose, perhaps.  Maybe this sounds petty, but his voice is not right either. It is too deep. I find Watson rather nondescript.  I would give the pair 2 out of 5 stars.  They just don't cut it.HOWARDRonald Howard appears in 39 tv episodes, which I shan't list here.I will preface this by saying that, at first, I distinctly disliked Howard as Holmes.  I must say he doesn't look very promising at first, as he doesn't have the classic Holmes "look" or face. He is also less dramatic than previous Sherlock Holmes'.  Once you get past this, and become used to the more casual, less all-brains type of Holmes, he is quite good.  Like I said, Howard does not shove the logical, calculating side of Holmes to the forefront.  You see more of his "other" side, where he teases Watson, and clearly amuses himself by mystifying Lestrade, and toying with chemicals and poisons in their sitting room.  Also, he has a perfect voice for Holmes- not deep or stuffy, slightly shrill.  H. Crawford's Watson is very good as well, he finds a good balance between seriousness and ridicule, though not exactly as the books portray him.  I would give both performances 4 out of 5 stars.MASSEY & OWENMassey is in THE SPECKLED BAND, and Owen is in A STUDY IN SCARLET.I will not venture to judge either performance, because I have not watched either in it's entirety.  From the little I saw of Reginald Owen, I did not like his Holmes.  I have not had the chance to view Raymond Massey, so I withhold judgement on his film.  I will say the A STUDY IN SCARLET is nothing like the book, it seems to be a combination of VALLEY OF FEAR, and CHARLES AUGUSTUS MILVERTON.

reviewText: My dad grew up with these movies, and for him, Basil Rathbone *is* Sherlock Holmes.  Some of our best times are spent watching the old movies he grew up with:  Charlie Chan, Sherlock Holmes, etc.  I received a $5 gift certificate, so I paid a very low price for nine movies - As I told my dad, he's worth at least a few cents to me. ;)Arthur Wontner simply isn't a very good Sherlock in either my dad's or my opinion.  He's not much of an actor, and these movies certainly don't live up to the books they stem from.  However, they're nice little slivers of history, and they are enjoyable.  The other two non-Rathbone films are much the same.  Basil Rathbone brings a little more fun and depth to Holmes, and overall, they're better quality films.  I would have paid the same money for just the four Rathbone movies, and it would be worth it.  These movies are a little funnier, a little more exciting, and just better-made.However, in several of the movies, guess who plays Watson?  Ian Fleming, the creator of James Bond!  He's also a handsome devil. ;)  He's a decent actor, to boot!One thing severely lacking is the film quality.  These films haven't been restored and look very "ratty."  I hope someone restores these old beauties to their former glory since Sherlock Holmes is making a comeback.

reviewText: These movies harken back to my youth (don't ask). I love the Basil Rathbone Sherlock; no sex, no profanity, no nudity and certainly no beautiful women. If there are women and they are beautiful surely they must be evil. Watson is of course a buffoon but that is as it should be. Holmes and his towering intellect makes all look stupid anyway. I love it!! A complete and perfect mental escape for me when I watch these short almost vignettes.
